title: On Radial Isotropic Position: Theory and Algorithms Work on this paper by Shiri Artstein was supported in part by the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement No. 770127), and in part by ISF grant 665/15. Work by Haim Kaplan was supported in part by by ISF grant 1595/19 and grant 1367/2016 from the German-Israeli Science Foundation (GIF). Work by Micha Sharir was supported in part by Grant 260/18 from the Israel Science Foundation, Grant G-1367-407.6/2016 from the German-Israeli Foundation for Scientific Research and Development, by the Blavatnik Research Fund in Computer Science at Tel Aviv University, and by the Israeli Centers of Research Excellence (I-CORE) program (Center No. 4/11).

sections.putting a set in radial isotropic positi:
In this section we survey the theory of radial isotropy. Several ways to develop this theory
have been proposed in the literature 2    ,
and we follow the approach of Barthe , with our interpretation, clarifications,
and some enhancements, including some features from the analysis of Carlen et al. .
We give a brief summary here that is sufficient to present, develop and analyze our algorithms.
For a complete presentation, including the proofs, we refer the reader to Appendix A. To state the various equivalent conditions for attaining radial isotropy, we introduce the basis polytope
associated with a set X𝑋X of vectors. The “basis polytope” associated with a set X={xi}i=1n⊂ℝd𝑋superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑X=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} is the {0,1}01\{0,1\}-polytope where 𝟏Ssubscript1𝑆{\bf 1}_{S} is the n𝑛n-dimensional indicator vector of the set S𝑆S. We also use the equivalent representation of KXsubscript𝐾𝑋K_{X} given by Carlen et al. . [Carlen, Lieb and Loss ]

position. Moreover, Φ∗​(c)superscriptΦ𝑐\Phi^{*}(c) is attained at the point t∗∈ℝnsuperscript𝑡superscriptℝ𝑛t^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} if and only if
the matrix Q−1/2​(t∗)superscript𝑄12superscript𝑡Q^{-1/2}(t^{*}) puts X𝑋X in radial c𝑐c-isotropic position,
where, as above, Q​(t∗)=∑i=1neti∗​xi⊗xi𝑄superscript𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛tensor-productsuperscript𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖Q(t^{*})=\sum_{i=1}^{n}e^{t^{*}_{i}}x_{i}\otimes x_{i}. Clearly, the vector t∗superscript𝑡t^{*} that attains Φ∗​(c)superscriptΦ𝑐\Phi^{*}(c) has to satisfy

irreducibility assumption (described shortly), the radial c𝑐c-isotropic position is unique up to rotation. The function ΦΦ\Phi is linear in the all-1 direction 𝟏=𝟏[n]1subscript1delimited-[]𝑛{\bf 1}={\bf 1}_{[n]}.
The existence of other directions of linearity turns out to depend on the dimension of the polytope
KXsubscript𝐾𝑋K_{X} and is equivalent to a notion of irreducibility that we describe next.
Given a set X={xi}i=1n𝑋superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑛X=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} of vectors in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d},
we define an equivalence relation ∼similar-to\sim on [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n], considered in Barthe , as follows:
Two indices i,j𝑖𝑗i,j satisfy i∼jsimilar-to𝑖𝑗i\sim j if there exists a subset S⊂[n]𝑆delimited-[]𝑛S\subset[n],
|S|=d−1𝑆𝑑1|S|=d-1, such that S1=S∪{i}subscript𝑆1𝑆𝑖S_{1}=S\cup\{i\} and S2=S∪{j}subscript𝑆2𝑆𝑗S_{2}=S\cup\{j\} both satisfy ΔSi>0subscriptΔsubscript𝑆𝑖0\Delta_{S_{i}}>0
(we show in Appendix A.7, that this relation is
an equivalence relation444In earlier treatments (as in ), transitivity was not established, and the relation
was made transitive by taking its transitive completion.).
The equivalence classes of ∼similar-to\sim form a partition [n]=σ1∪⋯∪σkdelimited-[]𝑛subscript𝜎1⋯subscript𝜎𝑘[n]=\sigma_{1}\cup\cdots\cup\sigma_{k}.
Letting Ej=span​{xi∣i∈σj}subscript𝐸𝑗spanconditional-setsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖subscript𝜎𝑗E_{j}=\mathrm{span}\{x_{i}\mid i\in\sigma_{j}\}, for j=1,…,k𝑗1…𝑘j=1,\ldots,k, it was shown in Barthe  that
ℝd=⨁j=1kEjsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗1𝑘subscript𝐸𝑗\mathbb{R}^{d}=\bigoplus_{j=1}^{k}E_{j}, and this is the maximal splitting of
ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} into a direct sum of subspaces that collectively contain all the vectors of X𝑋X. The dimension of the affine hull of KXsubscript𝐾𝑋K_{X} is equal to n−k𝑛𝑘n-k, where k𝑘k
is the number of equivalence classes of the equivalence relation ∼similar-to\sim. When there is only one equivalence class, we say that X𝑋X is irreducible;
in this case the only affine subspace that contains KXsubscript𝐾𝑋K_{X} is ∑zi=dsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑑\sum z_{i}=d.
In the reducible case we have additional affine subspaces that
contain KXsubscript𝐾𝑋K_{X}, given by ∑i∈σjzi=dim(Ej)subscript𝑖subscript𝜎𝑗subscript𝑧𝑖dimensionsubscript𝐸𝑗\sum_{i\in\sigma_{j}}z_{i}=\dim(E_{j}), for each j=1,…,k𝑗1…𝑘j=1,\ldots,k,
and additional linearity directions, as shown in the following lemma. Assume that the set X𝑋X admits a maximal splitting into subsets Xjsubscript𝑋𝑗X_{j} contained in
respective components Ejsubscript𝐸𝑗E_{j} of a direct sum ℝd=⨁j=1kEjsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗1𝑘subscript𝐸𝑗\mathbb{R}^{d}=\bigoplus_{j=1}^{k}E_{j},
with a corresponding maximal index splitting [n]=σ1∪⋯∪σkdelimited-[]𝑛subscript𝜎1⋯subscript𝜎𝑘[n]=\sigma_{1}\cup\cdots\cup\sigma_{k},
so that Ej=span​{xi∣i∈σj}subscript𝐸𝑗spanconditional-setsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖subscript𝜎𝑗E_{j}={\rm span}\{x_{i}\mid i\in\sigma_{j}\} for each j𝑗j. Then
Φ​((1−λ)​t+λ​s)=(1−λ)​Φ​(t)+λ​Φ​(s)Φ1𝜆𝑡𝜆𝑠1𝜆Φ𝑡𝜆Φ𝑠\Phi((1-\lambda)t+\lambda s)=(1-\lambda)\Phi(t)+\lambda\Phi(s), for λ∈ℝ𝜆ℝ\lambda\in\mathbb{R},
if and only if t=s+∑i=1kαj​𝟏σj𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝛼𝑗subscript1subscript𝜎𝑗t=s+\sum_{i=1}^{k}\alpha_{j}{\bf 1}_{\sigma_{j}}, for any choice of scalars αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j}. When ΦΦ\Phi is reducible, we get a partition of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} into a nontrivial direct sum
⨁j=1kEjsuperscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗1𝑘subscript𝐸𝑗\bigoplus_{j=1}^{k}E_{j}.
If Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} and Ejsubscript𝐸𝑗E_{j} are orthogonal for every pair i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j then one can check that
Φ​(t)=∑j=1kΦj​((ti)i∈σj)Φ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑘subscriptΦ𝑗subscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑖subscript𝜎𝑗\Phi(t)=\sum_{j=1}^{k}\Phi_{j}((t_{i})_{i\in\sigma_{j}}),
where ΦjsubscriptΦ𝑗\Phi_{j} is the restriction of ΦΦ\Phi to Ejsubscript𝐸𝑗E_{j}.
Consequently, everything else factorizes too, so
Φ∗​(c)=∑j=1kΦj∗​((ci)i∈σj)superscriptΦ𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑘superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑗subscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑖subscript𝜎𝑗\Phi^{*}(c)=\sum_{j=1}^{k}\Phi_{j}^{*}((c_{i})_{i\in\sigma_{j}}),
and the domain of Φ∗superscriptΦ\Phi^{*} is the intersection of the domains of the Φj∗subscriptsuperscriptΦ𝑗\Phi^{*}_{j}’s.
Furthermore, the optimization problem of finding a vector t𝑡t that maximizes ⟨c,t⟩−Φ​(t)𝑐𝑡Φ𝑡\langle c,t\rangle-\Phi(t),
which we handle using gradient descent (in Section 4), decomposes too into
irreducible independent subproblems. In case ΦΦ\Phi is reducible but some pairs of the subspaces in the decomposition ℝd=⨁j=1mEjsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗1𝑚subscript𝐸𝑗\mathbb{R}^{d}=\bigoplus_{j=1}^{m}E_{j}
are not orthogonal, we first transform X𝑋X into isotropic position (not necessarily radial).
After the transformation, the decomposition becomes orthogonal and the problem decomposes,
as the following lemma shows. Let X𝑋X be a set of n𝑛n vectors in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} in c𝑐c-isotropic position, and assume that
ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} is the direct sum F1⊕F2direct-sumsubscript𝐹1subscript𝐹2F_{1}\oplus F_{2} such that each vector of X𝑋X lies in F1∪F2subscript𝐹1subscript𝐹2F_{1}\cup F_{2}.
Then F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} and F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} are orthogonal.
